_header: Deceit deceiveth and shall be deceived
Bibliographic Ghosts:
London, Lambeth Palace Library Carew 623 [Book of Howth], p. 84: Hamer (1995)
XHamer, Richard. A Manuscript Index to the Index of Middle English Verse. London: British Library, 1995 could not find, in spite of Brown and Robbins (1943)
XCarleton Fairchild Brown, and Rossell Hope Robbins. The Index of Middle English Verse. New York: Printed for the Index Society by Columbia University Press, 1943 reference to editions, Brewer and Bullen (1867)
XJ. S. Brewer, and William Bullen. Calendar of the Carew Manuscripts Preserved in the Archiepiscopal Library at Lambeth. 6 vols. Public Record Office Texts and Calendars. London: 1867-73; Seymour (1929)
XSeymour, St. John Delincourt. Anglo-Irish Literature, 1200-1582. Cambridge: at the UP, 1929; and several repr, 99.
_description: A single stanza (Bk. II, lines 4432-8) from Lydgate’s Fall of Princes (1904) — rhyme royal.

BodAuct7Q221.Transcription:
Disceit disceyuyth & shalbe deceyvidffor who bi disceit is
                    deceyvableThofe his disceit be not owt perceyvidTo such a deceyvour
                    deceyt is retornableffraude quyt with fraude is guerdon coverableThofe
                    fraude of defraudour be not son owt fowndTo such a defraudour yet
                        sha frawde shall ay rebound
BodAuct7Q221.Note:
Added to last paper leaf of volume by a hand of the sixteenth century,
                    after end of printed text 3 pages previously; Hamer (1995)
XHamer,  Richard. 
             A Manuscript Index to the Index of Middle English Verse.
         London: British Library, 1995 lists as
                    ‘number does not exist’ since listed as Auct. 7.Q.21 in Brown  and  Robbins (1943)
XCarleton Fairchild Brown,   and  Rossell Hope Robbins.  
             The Index of Middle English Verse.
         New York: Printed for the Index Society by Columbia University Press,
            1943; also several later transcripts on same page, including
                    that cited by Brown  and  Robbins (1943)
XCarleton Fairchild Brown,   and  Rossell Hope Robbins.  
             The Index of Middle English Verse.
         New York: Printed for the Index Society by Columbia University Press,
            1943, ‘Deceit decieveth & shal be
                    decievid / For lo by Deciet is decievable…’.

BodDou45.First Lines:
Deceyt deceyvyth & shalbe deceyuydffor who by deceyt is
                    deceyuable…
BodDou45.Last Lines:
…ffor who by fraude is fraudulent foundeTo a defraudour fraude
                    will ay rebounde

BodFair16.First Lines:
Deceyt disceyveth and shal be deceyvedffor by deceyt who is
                    deceyvable…
BodFair16.Last Lines:
…ffor whoo with fraude fraudelent ys foundeTo a defrauder
                    fraude wol ay rebounde
BodFair16.Note: As a separate text between end of 3312 and beginning of 6798.
BodFair16.Facsimiles:
Norton-Smith,  John. 
             “Introduction.” 
             Bodleian Library MS Fairfax 16.
         London: Scolar Press, 1979.

BodHat73.First Lines:
Dysceyt disceyueth and shal be disceyvedffor by disceyt who that is
                    disceyvable…
BodHat73.Last Lines:
…ffor who with fraude fraudulent is foundeTo such defraudor
                    fraude wele ay rebounde
BodHat73.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 100.

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Disceyte deceyueþe and shal beo deceyuedffor by disceyte who
                    þat is desceyvableÞaughe heos disceytes beo not
                    aperceyvableTo a desceyuous disceytes beon retournable…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…ffor whoo with fraude þat fraudelent is foundeTil a
                    defraudour fraude wol ay Rebounde
CamTCC600.Note:
Rhymes abbbbcc because scribe miswrites line 3; with Latin equivalent
                    below, beg. ‘Dampno quid peneris vuulnus quid vuulnere
                    morbus…’.

BLHar7578.Transcription:
[D]eceit destayneth and shal be desteynedeffor by disceit who is
                    disteynableThough his deceyte be not a perceyuedeTo a desceyoure
                    desceyt is retornableffor who with fraude fraudelent is foundeTo a
                    defrauder fraude wel ay rebounde
BLHar7578.Note:
Initial ‘D’ is missing, with space left for illuminated
                    initial.

BLSl1825.First Lines:
Disceite disceyeth and shall b[ ]yuedffor by disceyte who ys
                    disceyuableThough hys disceytis be not oute perceyuedTo a disceyuour
                    disceyte ys retornableffraude quit with fraude is guerdoun
                    conuenableffor who with fraude fraudelent ys foundTo a defrauder
                    fraude wol aye rebound
BLSl1825.Note:
Second copy in manuscript, added to MS by a hand of the fifteenth or
                    sixteenth century. Different from that on f. 90v.

NLWPork10.Editions:
Kurvinen,  Auvo. 
             “MS. Porkington 10. Description with Extracts.” 
             Neuphilologische Mitteilungen
         54 (1953): 33-67: 62.

Banna.First Lines:
Dissait dissauis and salbe dissauitquha with dissait is
                    dissauable…
Banna.Last Lines:
…and quha with fraud Is frawdfully ay fundTo þe
                    defraudour defraud sall ay redound
Banna.Note: One stanza rhyme royal in this MS
Banna.Facsimiles:
Fox,  Denton,  and  William A. Ringler.  
             The Bannatyne Manuscript: National Library of Scotland Advocates’
                MS. 1.1.6
         London: Scolar Press, in Association with The National Library of
            Scotland, 1980.
Banna.Editions:
Murdoch,  James Barclay. 
             The Bannatyne Manuscript.
             4 vols. in 11 parts, paged continuously. 
             Hunterian Club
         16, 32, 40, 46, 50, 55-56, 64-67 Glasgow: Anderson, 1873-1896: 202.

NLS1931.First Lines:
Deceyte deceyvyt and schall be deceyuydffor by deceyte who is
                    deceyvable…
NLS1931.Last Lines:
…for who by fraude fraudelent is fondeTo a defrauder defraude
                    wyll ay rebound
NLS1931.Facsimiles:
Hardman,  Phillipa. 
             The Heege Manuscript: A Facsimile of National Library of Scotland MS
                Advocates 19.3.1.
         Leeds Texts and Monographs, n.s. 16. Leeds: School of English,
            2000.

Ritchie,  W. Tod,
                        ed.  
             The Bannatyne Manuscript.
             4 parts in 4 vols. 
             Scottish Text Society
         3rd ser. 5 (1928); n.s. 22 (1928); n.s. 23 (1930); n.s. 26 (1934)
            Edinburgh and London: Blackwood, 1928-34; ed. by Ritchie et al: 2.184.

NottsULMeLm1.First Lines:
Dysceyt dysceyvyth and shall be dysceyvedffor who by dysceyt ys
                    dysceyvableThough hys dysceyt be not owt perseyvedTo a dysceyuour
                    disceytes ben retornable…
NottsULMeLm1.Last Lines:
…ffor who with frawde frawdently is fowndeTo euery suche man
                    frawde wull euer rebounde

PierpontM775.First Lines:
Desceyt desceyueth and shall be deseyuedffor be descey who is
                    deseyuable…
PierpontM775.Last Lines:
ffor who with fraude fraudelent is foundeTo a defraudour fraude wil
                    ay rebounde
PierpontM775.Note:
Immediately follows 6798
                    as if continuation of same.
